instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
Hi, this board came in very slow, not detecting battery, and maximum fan spin, built in asd say battery is not detected and there's a problem with smc, but from experience, i can solved this with change battery.. the question is, can i repair the sensor which located at the battery mini board ?
is there any schematic for the little battery board ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
No way, try known good battery.
Internal processor has setted an error flag.
Cells are good, but battery is locked...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message: if i used known good's battery's mini board and replaced it to this error one, would it work ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message: okayy now I understand the scumbagness of this T2, thanks sirr

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
Is not about T2.
Each battery pack has an internal processor; special sofyware and interface required to unlock an error flag.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
i fucked up.
I was soldering speaker connector which customer tore, and i FORGET to unplugged the battery, i think i saw a spark at a caps at headphone port which is a ppbus caps. ( connected by j6100 ) , I straight away think this is a t2 problem.. but after many hours trying to dfu, still cannot.
I then remeasure power rail, and I found out <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> is shorted, resistance to ground at 2 ohm, but injecting power doesnt heat anything

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> shorted with J6100 disconnected.
If yes, I can suspect T2 is dead now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not detecting battery
threads.message:
yeah, im in just in denial, t2 is warmy after all.
I have speak to the customer about this. and he agreed to upgrade to 2019 macbook air with some fee, thank god no critical data needed..
